    Non-ergodicity in a simple coin game

    Based on a seminal talk by Ole Peters, I illustrate the fundamental difference between an ergodic and non-ergodic process using a simple coin game.

    (If you download this notebook, you can use the interactive widgets to explore this yourself)

    Dynamics:

    • At each time step a fair coin is flipped and lands either heads or tails.
    • For heads wealth increases with 50% e.g.
    • For tails wealth decreases by 40% e.g.

    Nonclamenture:

    • is the wealth at time (W_)
    • is the large-N limit expectation average (E_)
    • is the the long-time average (A_)
    • is the emperical mean (mu)

    Initial analysis:

    Simulations:

    import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

from ipywidgets import interact, interactive, fixed
import ipywidgets as widgets

sns.set(style="white", palette="muted", color_codes=True)

%matplotlib inline

    def multiplicativeW( T, N, W, E, A, mu, phi ):
    
    w0 = 1 
    c1 = 0.5 
    c2 = -0.4
    
    j = N
    k = T
    
    size = (N,T)
    
    coinToss = np.zeros(size)
    
    W_ = np.zeros(size)
    E_ = np.zeros(T)
    A_ = np.zeros(T)
    mu_ = np.zeros(T)
    phi_ = np.zeros(size)
    
    np.random.seed(1); 
    
    for j in range(N):
        
        
        
        for k in range(T):
            if k == 0:
                
                W_[j,k] = w0
                E_[k] = w0
                A_[k] = w0
                mu_[k] = w0
                
            else:
                
                # coin dynamics 
                coinToss[j,k] = np.random.choice([c1,c2])
                
                # wealth dynamics
                W_[j,k] = W_[j,k-1] * (1+coinToss[j,k])
                
                # theoretical constants
                E_[k] = w0 + np.power(1+((0.5*c1)+(0.5*c2)),[k])
                A_[k] = np.power(np.exp((np.log(1+c1)+np.log(1+c2))/2),[k])
                
                # emperical mean
                mu_[k] = np.mean(W_[:,k])
    
    fig = plt.figure(figsize=(12,5))
    plt.yscale('log', nonposy='clip')
    
    NUM_COLORS = N
    cm = sns.cubehelix_palette(8, start=.5, rot=-.75,as_cmap = True)
    
    ax1 = fig.add_subplot(1,1,1)
    ax1.set_color_cycle([cm(1.*i/NUM_COLORS) for i in range(NUM_COLORS)])
    
    if W is True:
    
        for j in range(N):
            ax1.plot(W_[j],linewidth = 1)
        
    if E is True:    
        ax1.plot(E_,linewidth = 2,color='k',label = (r'$\mathbb{E}$'))
        plt.legend(loc='upper left', fontsize=14)
        
    if A is True:
        ax1.plot(A_,linewidth = 2,color='r', label = (r'$\mathcal{A}$'))
        plt.legend(loc='upper left', fontsize=14)
        
    if mu is True:
        ax1.plot(mu_,linewidth = 2,color='r', label = (r'$\mu$'))
        plt.legend(loc='upper left', fontsize=14)

    First, let’s assume that we play the coin game once every minute for an hour and plot just one () instance of the dynamic outlined above for time periods.

    interact(multiplicativeW, T = 60, N = 1, W = True, E = False, A = False, mu = False, phi = False)

    Its clear that this process got close to zero quite quickly (after 50 flips)! However, it’s also very noisy and difficult to make out if this one trajectory was just a bit unfortunate. Lets repeat the game 100 times and see what happens.

    interact(multiplicativeW, T = 60, N = 100, W = True, E = False, A = False, mu = False, phi = False)

    We’re still not getting much smarter. Looks like half on the trajectories are increasing, while the other half is decreasing, but its quite difficult to tell. Lets try to average the 100 different trajectories and see what that looks like.

    interact(multiplicativeW, T = 60, N = 100, W = True, E = False, A = False, mu = True, phi = False)

    Well, that looks very flat at around 0. Lets increase the number of times we play to instead and see if we can get a more conclusive graphical result.

    interact(multiplicativeW, T = 60, N = 10000, W = False, E = False, A = False, mu = True, phi = False)

    Alright! It seems like the empirical average steadily increases. If you feel like removing more noise, you can increase (however this script is quite slow due to all the if-loops).

    Another thing we could do was to calculate the theoretical mean or expectation operator . We calculate this as

    where denotes the average over N (e.g. 10000 in the figure above). We denote this .

    Let’s calculate this. By using our knowledge that as 

    interact(multiplicativeW, T = 60, N = 10000, W = False, E = True, A = False, mu = True, phi = False)

    Clearly the theoretical mean (or expectation operator) increases towards infinity, and it seems that the emperical mean converges to the theoretical prediction quite well.

    It seems like this might be a favorable gamble! Actually, this gamble has infininte expected payoff, which means that you (and everyone else who has positively increasing utility in increasing wealth) should take this gamble.. Right?

    Perhaps surprisingly, the answer turns out to be a resounding no.

    The time-perspective

    To convince ourselves about this, lets plot one ‘person’ playing the game for trials and contrast this to the theoretical mean.

    interact(multiplicativeW, T = 10000, N = 1, W = True, E = True, A = False, mu = False, phi = False)

    This single trajectory is quite a different scenario from what the theoretical prediction is. While the expectation operator goes to (which is a very, very large number), the realised trajectory ends up at , that is, a zero followed by 227 zeros!

    Let’s try to convince ourselves that we’re not just being unlucky and increase the number of players, playing to .

    interact(multiplicativeW, T = 10000, N = 100, W = True, E = True, A = False, mu = False, phi = False)

    Immediatly there seems to be a fundamental difference between the theoretical prediction and the hundred realised trajectories.

    This difference can be explained by considering a rough definition of ergodicity:

    A process is non-ergodic if the time-average does not equal the ensemble-average.

    Lets consider the definition of the finite-time time-average

    where denotes the average of process over time . Similar to the above, taking the time-limit of this gives us the theoretical time-average

    which we denote .

    Lets plot both , and some data to see which theoretical prediction suits the simulated data the best (you probably already know the anwser).

    interact(multiplicativeW, T = 10000, N = 100, W = True, E = True, A = True, mu = False, phi = False)

    So what is happening here? Well, hopefully you’ve just realised that a process that grows multiplicatively, just like , is non-ergodic.

    This means that the ensemble average, mean or expectation operator does not yield the same as the time-average, which is what we’ve shown in the figures above.

    Why is this important?

    Well - that’s a really good question. If you ask an economist, or just borrow one of his thick books on micro economics or decision making, the anwser will be along the lines of “If the expected payout is positive, then you should go for it!”. Well, now we’ve seen that this might not be a very good idea. The expectation operator is used very widely in economics and other fields of decision-making - sadly often without too much consideration about the dynamics.

    There’s much more to this story and if you find it compelling, I suggest you see the video in the introduction, or read the follow papers:

    1) The time resolution of the St Petersburg paradox

    2) Evaluating Gambles Using Dynamics

    Updated: January 12, 2017
